properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, and possible ice pellets and freezing rain. Total snowfall: near 15 cm, and possibly more. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine. Time span: Thursday evening to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin this evening and continue tonight and Friday. The snow is expected to become mixed with ice pellets Friday afternoon and possibly with freezing rain Friday evening, before the precipitation changes back to snow later Friday night. At this time, forecast guidance indicates that the area of heaviest snowfall will remain just west of the Islands, but this could change if the track of the system bringing the snow shifts further to the east. Strong northeasterly winds Friday afternoon and evening, followed by strong northwesterly winds early Saturday morning, will cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. Snow is expected to taper off to flurries Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:42:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T14:43:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2262370449.2020
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chills are in the minus 45 to minus 50 range in parts of northernmost Manitoba. Wind chills should moderate somewhat this afternoon. However, extreme wind chills are likely to return for Thursday night and into Friday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T02:34:51-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 30 to 50 centimetres of snow is expected by Friday evening. Snow will intensify this evening and persist through Friday. In addition, strong northeast winds will gust up to 60 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will cause blowing snow over several areas of Southern and Central Quebec. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing drizzle will continue today. Snow becoming heavy at times tonight. Light freezing rain over southern portions of the Niagara Peninsula is also possible today. Light snow with patchy freezing drizzle will continue today. This evening, snow may become heavy at times before tapering off to light snow by Friday morning. Total snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 10 cm range are expected for most areas, with 10 to 15 cm possible for portions of the Niagara Peninsula by the time the snow tapers off late Friday afternoon. The afternoon commute is likely to be affected. The Friday morning commute may also be affected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T09:00:18-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Locations: central and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Periods of snow will develop by morning on Friday. Snowfall rates will be relatively light during the day on Friday, but will become heavy, at times on, Friday night. Over some areas, the snow may mix with ice pellets later Friday night. Snow will continue into Saturday with strengthening northerly winds resulting in blowing snow. The snow and wind will begin to ease over most areas by late Saturday, but onshore flurries and snow squalls may persist over parts of western Newfoundland into Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:08:27-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and freezing rain are expected, followed by large waves, pounding surge and elevated sea water levels. Total snowfall and ice pellets: 10 to 15 cm (late tonight through Friday). Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm (Friday night). Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly 80 to 100 km/h (Saturday). Wave heights: 6 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore (Saturday). Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques to Connaigre. Remarks: Snow will begin overnight and change to ice pellets during the day on Friday. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening, and then eventually change to a brief period of rain before ending overnight Friday night. Strong southwesterly winds will develop on Saturday morning and ease Saturday afternoon. Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the southwest, especially near the morning high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:09:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T14:10:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2029653128.2020
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow and ice pellets are expected, followed by freezing rain. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: near 15 cm. Locations: northwestern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: Flurries will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning. A transition to ice pellets will then slowly migrate northward over the region Friday morning and afternoon. Extreme northern areas will likely receive near 15 cm of snow before the transition. Further south, snowfall totals are expected to be lower, but will be followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain Friday evening and eventually to rain later Friday night. A freezing rain warning may be required with subsequent forecasts. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:05:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-06T14:06:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4132473446.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected tonight and Friday. Total snowfall: 15 to 35 cm, possibly more. Locations: northern and parts of central New Brunswick. Time span: near noon today to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of light snow will begin near noon today. Current guidance indicates that there will be a break in the snow this evening, then it will re-intensify overnight and become heavy at times throughout the day on Friday. Snow will continue through Friday night and then taper off to flurries Saturday morning. Additionally, strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, followed by a prolonged period of ice pellets and then freezing rain is expected. Total snow and ice pellet amounts: 10 to 15 cm. Total freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm except 15 to 25 mm along the southern shore. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Locations: Metro St. John's and the eastern Avalon Peninsula. Remarks: Snow will begin overnight and then change to ice pellets Friday morning. The ice pellets will change to freezing rain later Friday morning along the southern shore, while further north (including the Metro St. John's area), the ice pellets are expected to be more prolonged before eventually changing to to freezing rain late Friday afternoon. The freezing rain will change to rain near midnight Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Utility outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:04:59-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, ice pellets and freezing rain expected for the end of the week. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, and possibly more over Prince County. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: this afternoon to Saturday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow will begin this afternoon and persist through Thursday night. A changeover to ice pellets and or freezing rain is expected to occur Friday, before precipitation changes back to snow Friday night. Strong easterly winds Friday night into Saturday morning may also cause reduced visibility in snow and blowing snow. The snow is expected to taper off Saturday morning. It is still uncertain where and when the changeover between snow and mixed precipitation will occur, which will affect the amount and location of the heaviest snowfall and the areas most likely to be threatened by freezing rain. Warnings may be issued with future forecasts as the system approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm. Locations: along the Atlantic coast of central Nova Scotia. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: The snow will change through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight, then to rain Friday morning as temperatures rise above freezing. Along the Atlantic coast, where temperatures are expected to be slightly warmer, precipitation will fall largely as rain tonight. Total rainfall accumulations of 15 to 30 mm are forecast, with the highest amounts expected along the coast. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, and possibly more in some locations. Locations: southwestern Nova Scotia. Time span: early this evening until Friday evening. Remarks: The snow will change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain by early this evening. Periods of rain will continue, heavy at times, until Friday afternoon or evening. Total rainfall accumulations of 20 to 40 mm are forecast, with the highest amounts expected over Cape Sable Island and vicinity. Freezing rain warnings have also been issued for this event because inland areas are likely to see a more prolonged period of freezing rain, beginning early this evening and continuing until an approaching warm front causes temperatures to rise above freezing overnight tonight. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An approaching Pacific low pressure system is giving precipitation to parts of the southwest interior. Periods of freezing rain over the Similkameen region will change to snow near noon. As the low moves to the east, the snow will end by late this evening with total accumulations of 10 cm expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to a long-lasting period of freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: 10 to 20 mm. Locations: Burin Peninsula. Time span: Friday afternoon until midnight Friday night. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow tonight before changing to ice pellets Friday morning, and then to freezing rain Friday afternoon. The freezing rain is expected to change to rain near midnight Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Significant snowfall expected today. Snowfall will return to Allison Pass this morning as a Pacific low pressure system approaches the south coast. The snow is expected to last into this evening giving accumulations of 15 to 20 cm. The snow is forecast to end by late this evening as the low moves to the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Locations: southern coastal Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Friday morning until Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow will quickly change through ice pellets and freezing rain to rain over southernmost sections of the Avalon Peninsula on Friday morning. The rain will continue, heavy at times, through the day on Friday, and eventually spread inland and northward Friday night. The rain will end Saturday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:02:12-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula, excluding southernmost coastal areas. Time span: Friday morning until midnight Friday night. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow tonight before changing to ice pellets Friday morning. Over southernmost coastal areas, a quick transition through freezing rain to rain is expected to occur Friday morning. Elsewhere, the transition will take much longer, resulting in a prolonged period of freezing rain. Precipitation is expected to change to rain over all areas by midnight Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow will continue today and become heavy at times tonight into Friday morning. Snow will continue Friday before tapering off Friday night. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are likely by Friday night. The commute this evening may be impacted. The Friday morning commute is a much higher concern. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values near -55 are occurring. Temperatures and wind chill values are forecast to moderate early this afternoon, although wind chill values are again expected to approach -55 Friday evening. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. A total of 20 to 40 centimetres of snow is expected through Saturday morning. In addition, strong northeast winds will gust up to 70 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will create widespread blowing snow over several areas of Central and Eastern Quebec. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with patchy freezing drizzle today. Snow heavy at times tonight. Periods of snow will continue today with patchy freezing drizzle possible. Snow will become heavy at times tonight into early Friday morning. Additional light snowfall is expected Friday before the snow finally comes to an end Friday evening. Total snowfall accumulations in the 10 to 15 cm range are possible by Friday evening. The evening commute is likely to be impacted by this snowfall. The Friday morning commute may also be affected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain amounts: possibly more than to 20 mm over some inland areas, with lesser amounts over southwestern Nova Scotia and along the coast. Location: Nova Scotia. Time span: beginning early this evening in the southwest and continuing into Friday evening over some northern regions. Remarks: Developing snow today will transition through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight. The freezing rain will begin early this evening in southwestern Nova Scotia and spread northeastward tonight. In the southwest, freezing rain is expected to quickly change to rain along the coast, but may continue into the overnight hours further inland. The remainder of Nova Scotia will see a prolonged period of freezing rain, which will gradually transition to rain on Friday from south to north as temperatures rise above freezing. Some inland areas may receive total freezing rain accumulations of 20 mm or more from this event. On Friday evening, strong southwesterly winds are expected to develop across much of the province, particularly along the Atlantic coast and the Bay of Fundy. It is possible that wind warnings will be issued with future forecasts. In addition, higher than normal water levels are likely along the Atlantic coast near high tide Friday evening. Later on Friday night, winds will diminish and shift to northwesterly as a cold front crossing the province brings snow flurries and a rapid drop to cooler temperatures. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and extremely hazardous. Extended and widespread utility outages are possible. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-07T06:49:01-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. An extended period of freezing rain is expected tonight and Friday. Locations: Fundy Coast. Time span: beginning tonight and continuing into Friday evening. Remarks: The snow will transition through ice pellets to freezing rain tonight. Freezing rain, mixing at times with ice pellets, will continue through the day on Friday, except near Grand Manan Island, where temperatures will remain above zero and rain is expected throughout tonight and Friday. Freezing rain or rain will transition to periods of snow Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
